OBITUARIES THE RECORD L-5 FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 2010 Daniel DeRose 82; founded soup base firm By JAY LEVIN STAFF WRITER Daniel DeRose Jr. of Wyckoff, who probably had something to do with that bowl of minestrone you had for lunch, died Tuesday. He was 82. Mr. DeRose was founder and president of Major Products Co .

in Little Ferry, a global manufacturer of soup base, gravies and seasonings. The company was born 59 years ago in the garage behind the DeRose family home on Verona Avenue in Newark. Using a wood-and-cast-iron mixer built by his father, Mr. DeRose made powdered stock from chicken fat and other ingredients and began peddling it to area restaurants and food service companies. The Syracuse University graduate had earlier sold apple cider vinegar .

"It was something easy to make, there was a need for it, and he could sell it. He did his best to become the king of soup base," said his son Daniel III, general manager of Major Products. By BOB THOMAS THE ASSOCIATED PRESS LOS ANGELES Kathryn Grayson, whose beauty and lilting soprano voice brightened such popular MGM musicals of the 1940s and 1950s as "Anchors Aweigh," "Show Boat" and "Kiss Me Kate," has died at age 88 .

Ms. Grayson died Wednesday at her Los Angeles home, said the actress' longtime secretary and companion, Sally Sherman. "She just went to sleep and didn't wake up," Sherman said Thursday. Ms. Grayson's youthful ambition was to sing opera, but she wasn't able to accomplish that dream until after her movie career ended .

While still a teenager, she was placed under contract at MGM at a time when the studio was assembling a stable of musical talent that would dominate the era of great musicals. Like Lana Turner, Esther Williams, Donna Reed and other MGM newcomers, Ms. Grayson was given a tryout as Mickey Rooney's sweetheart in the studio's popular Andy Hardy film series. He began writing for London's Sunday Express that year as an expert racing correspondent, an arrangement that continued for 16 years. Inspired by the success of his autobiography, and the slim wages of journalism, Mr. Francis decided to write a crime mystery about a jockey who is killed in the middle of a race .

"Dead Cert" came out in 1962, and after that he wrote about a book a year. His books were devoured by millions, and fans took pride in Mr. Francis' attention to detail and realism. He won many awards, including the Mystery Writers of America's Edgar Allan Poe Award an unprecedented three times. His wife, the former Mary Brenchley, died in 2000 .

He is survived by two sons, Felix, with whom he co-authored recent books, and Merrick. Before Mr. Francis began his writing career, he was unsure whether he would be remembered for much else besides riding Devon Loch, the Queen Mother's fallen horse. Mr. Francis often said that if a mystery had FRANCIS not unfolded literally underneath his feet at the Grand National during the mid-1950s, he might never have started writing at all. Known as one of the most challenging events for horse and man, the course, just short of 4.5 miles, is filled with tall jumps that, if not cleared properly, often lead to fatal crashes. Mr .

Francis and his mount, Devon Loch, had survived the course and were in the lead strides away from the finish when the big brown gelding suddenly collapsed in a heap. After the incident, the horse stood up, apparently uninjured and healthy. News of the spectacular spill spread across Britain, where photos of the horse splayed out on the turf accompanied front-page news stories. Mr. Francis, then 37, retired from race riding months later, citing a body too plagued by injuries including six collar-bone breaks, five nose breaks, a fractured skull, a broken back and dislocated shoulders .

REES SHAPIRO WASHINGTON POST NEWS SERVICE Dick Francis, a champion jockey for the British royal family who turned to writing crime fiction and helped launch an immensely popular subgenre of mysteries set in the horse-racing world, died Sunday at a home he kept in the Cayman Islands. No cause of death was reported, but he was diagnosed with prostate cancer in the mid-1990s. He was 89 .

In a career spanning four decades and 42 novels, Mr. Francis sold more than 60 million books. His protagonists, often former jockeys themselves, caromed through page-turning murder plots and ruthless kidnapping schemes. They endured impossibly excruciating torture but solved the mystery, nabbed the bad guy and usually got the girl. Reviewers said Mr .

Francis captured the authentic smells, sounds and sights of the racetrack. Author Carol Flake once wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Francis' plots moved so quickly that "one is tempted to handicap his books rather than review them, assigning each a speed rating and a weight allowance." As a jockey in Britain after World War II, he won about 350 races during his nine-year career and was Champion Jockey of the 1953-54 season.
